instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.LCDBKLT_FB: What is LCDBKLT_FB? LCDBKLT_FB is a feedback line between backlight output and the feedback pin on the LED driver. When this connection is broken, backlight output will be equal to PPBUS_G3H voltage of the system rather than boosting. Since this point is the highest voltage in the system, it is the fastest to corrode when liquid damaged, so it is a very common point to check when there is no backlight. .
definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.BKLT_EN_R: What is BKLT_EN_R? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. The “_R” suffix means that the signal is asserted when it is high, as in 3.3v, which is the opposite of the “_L”  suffix.
definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message:
Hey Guys.

I have this <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no backlight.  On <TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR> pin i have 12.6v and pin 3 12.6 also. I checked <CAPACITOR>C8400</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R8401</RESISTOR>(80.6k) and <RESISTOR>R8402</RESISTOR> all good so the voltage divider works good no issue there and when measured direct pin 3 to 4 on <TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR> it's 80k. I have input on <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> on pin 5 and 18 i don't have output. All resistors around <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> are good expect <RESISTOR>R8432</RESISTOR> which should be 150k but it's 24.1. I removed it but then when measured directly it's 150k and i get diode value on <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_FB</SIGNAL>. Also i noticed that <RESISTOR>R8440</RESISTOR> which should be 1m it's 0.86 on 1m scale. Ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message:
Be aware, high value resistors will always indicate lower value measured onboard.
Is normal, because of influence of other components.

You've said no backlight, do you get image at least?
Test external video and USB activity.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message: Yes laptop working fine for a few months after loss of backlight the client had time to come now for repair they were using on external display

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message:
<CHIP>U8400</CHIP> requires enable signal on pin 17, but backlight is adjusted through I2C bus, connected to LCD assembly.
You must try known good compatible LCD assembly.
Apple got a lot of problems with them on the new machines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message: Yes many came for a flex repair <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> and <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> but this one i already tried with another screen and it's the same

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message:
Check <RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR>-53.
Post voltage and diode mode at SCL/SDA lines.

Do you get image for sure on internal LCD?
<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> is high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message: On both line 5v and 0.500 diode mode

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message:

<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> is high?"

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message: Yes i get image and  3.3v on <RESISTOR>R8442</RESISTOR> and 3.3v on <RESISTOR>R9826</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R9827</RESISTOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message: I found very low reading on <DIODE>D8410</DIODE> pin 2 side  0.012 diode mode

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message:
Disconnect LCD and check again.
If goes high, change LCD assembly.
If still low, then should be a filter cap.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message: Hi, i have same model [SIZE=7][B]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> [/B][/SIZE]with backlight issue. The problem is a bit weird. When you connect the charger it display fine on the screen the battery level but when you power on the device it display on the background but no backlight. I have tried to plug external screen with usb c adapter but no luck. The backlight IC  system seems to be working fine gives 51v-54v on <DIODE>D8410</DIODE> when its on but doesnt want to  give backlight image on. i have tried to go on recovery mode but it doesnt seems to be working that either. Any suggestions?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Please open new thread in the future.

"The backlight IC  system seems to be working fine gives 51v-54v on <DIODE>D8410</DIODE> when its on but doesnt want to  give backlight image on."
Because there is no connection with LED strip.
Check with Apple if machine is covered by "flexgate" program.
Don't touch motherboard, unless LCD connector is bad.
Your problem is on the LCD assembly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message:

Please open new thread in the future.

"The backlight IC  system seems to be working fine gives 51v-54v on <DIODE>D8410</DIODE> when its on but doesnt want to  give backlight image on."

Check with Apple if machine is covered by "flexgate" program.
Don't touch motherboard, unless LCD connector is bad.
Your problem is on the LCD assembly.
[/QUOTE]
 Could it be that the customer has reduced the light down to 0% ?  Customer doesnt remember the password for it and cant access to profile to enable the touch bar to work and try increase the lighting . Is there any other way to confirm if its the screen the issue? Why it display fine the charging ICON when you plug the charging cable and only has dim light when its on?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message:
Correct backlight voltage is 44V aprox.
Move/rotate the screen when the machine is turned on, the screen will probably flicker.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message:
I have attached the photo below. As soon as you lift the LCD you get that small battery icon that displays LCD light fine then when you turn on the MacBook it keeps staying on the backlight problem.  If you move it up and down slowly or faster it remains the same. It's an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> model 15".

When the MacBook is on the backlight power stays on 54.5volt  but when you lift the screen and it displays the battery logo its 44-48 volt

Do you still think it's an LCD issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04
threads.message:
Backlight voltage goes high because connection with LED strip is lost.
Try another LCD assembly...
